469: <p>The official Android Developers Blog now has a full article just about this very subject, <em><a href="http://android-developers.blogspot.com/2011/03/identifying-app-installations.html">Identifying App Installations</a></em>.</p>

<p>A <a href="http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build.html#SERIAL" rel="noreferrer">Serial</a> field was added to the <code>Build</code> class in API level 9 (Android 2.3 - Gingerbread). Documentation says it represents the hardware serial number. Thus it should be unique, if it exists on the device. </p>

<p>I don't know whether it is actually supported (=not null) by all devices with API level &gt;= 9 though.</p>
<p>How about the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Mobile_Equipment_Identity" rel="noreferrer">IMEI</a>. That is unique for Android or other mobile devices.</p>
470:
<p>I have calculated the formula below to make the conversions <code>dpi</code> to <code>dp</code> and <code>sp</code>
<a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/DoAxa.png" rel="noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/DoAxa.png" alt="enter image description here"></a></p>

<p>You can see the difference between <code>px</code> and <code>dp</code> from the below picture, and you can also find that the <code>px</code> and <code>dp</code> could not guarantee the same physical sizes on the different screens.</p>

<p><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/KFn2N.png" alt="enter image description here"></p>

<p>Anything related with the size of text and appearance must use <code>sp</code> or <code>pt</code>. Whereas, anything related to the size of the controls, the layouts, etc. must be used with <code>dp</code>.</p>

<p>You can use both <code>dp</code> and <code>dip</code> at its places.</p>
